quiz.title: Algebra 2: Unit 10 Quiz 6
quiz.subtitle: 10.6: Confidence Intervals (Introduction)
quiz.subject: Mathematics
quiz.topic: Estimating a population parameter using a range of values

questions.question: A survey of 400 people found that 60% support a new policy. Which of the following best describes the purpose of a confidence interval for this data?
options: To estimate the true percentage of the entire population that supports the policy
To prove that exactly 60% of the population supports the policy
To eliminate the possibility of any sampling error
To calculate the exact cost of the policy for every citizen
questions.explanation: A confidence interval provides a range of plausible values for a population parameter based on a sample statistic.

questions.question: If a 95% confidence interval for the average score on a test is [35, 45], what is the point estimate (sample mean)?
questions.explanation: The point estimate is the midpoint of the confidence interval. $(35 + 45) / 2 = 40$.

questions.question: In a 95% confidence interval, what does the '95%' represent?
options: The percentage of such intervals that would contain the true population parameter if the study were repeated many times
The probability that a single person in the sample is correct
The percentage of the population that was surveyed
The accuracy of the mathematical formulas used
questions.explanation: Confidence level refers to the long-run success rate of the method. If we took many samples, 95% of the resulting intervals would capture the true population mean.

questions.question: A researcher increases the sample size of a study from $n=100$ to $n=1000$. Assuming the confidence level remains the same, what happens to the width of the confidence interval?
options: It becomes narrower
It becomes wider
It stays exactly the same
It doubles in size
questions.explanation: As sample size ($n$) increases, the standard error decreases. Since the margin of error is smaller, the interval becomes more precise (narrower).

questions.question: A poll shows that a candidate has 52% support with a margin of error of $\pm 3\%$. What is the resulting confidence interval?
questions.explanation: The interval is calculated as $\text{Statistic} \pm \text{Margin of Error}$. $52 - 3 = 49$ and $52 + 3 = 55$.

questions.question: Which of the following would result in a wider confidence interval?
options: Increasing the confidence level from 90% to 99%
Decreasing the confidence level from 95% to 90%
Increasing the sample size
Decreasing the standard deviation of the data
questions.explanation: To be 'more confident' (e.g., 99%), you must widen the net to ensure you capture the true parameter.

questions.question: A sample of 100 batteries found a mean life of 40 hours with a margin of error of 2 hours at a 95% confidence level. If the company wants to report a margin of error of only 1 hour, what should they do?
options: Increase the sample size
Decrease the sample size
Increase the confidence level
Use a different brand of batteries
questions.explanation: To reduce the margin of error (make the interval narrower) without changing the confidence level, you must increase the sample size.

questions.question: A confidence interval for the value of a measurement is [12.50, 17.50]. What is the margin of error?
questions.explanation: The margin of error is half the width of the total interval. The total width is $17.50 - 12.50 = 5.00$. Half of that is $2.50$.

questions.question: A study reports: 'We are 95% confident that the true proportion of students who own a laptop is between 0.72 and 0.88.' What is the sample proportion ($\hat{p}$)?
questions.explanation: The sample proportion is the center of the interval: $(0.72 + 0.88) / 2 = 0.80$.

questions.question: If a population parameter is known to be outside of a 95% confidence interval calculated from a specific sample, what does this suggest?
options: The sample was one of the 5% of samples that do not capture the parameter
The math was definitely calculated incorrectly
The sample size was too large
The confidence interval should have been 100%
questions.explanation: A 95% confidence level means that by chance, 5% of all possible samples will produce intervals that miss the true population parameter.

scoreMessages.90: Great work! You have a solid grasp of how we estimate population values.
scoreMessages.70: Good job. Remember: Higher confidence requires a wider interval!
scoreMessages.50: Keep practicing the relationship between sample size and interval width.
scoreMessages.0: Confidence intervals are about 'plausible ranges.' Review the margin of error concept.
